Title: The Idiot
Author: Elif Batuman
My Review:
people say they wish they could read a certain book for the first time again. this is my third time reading the idiot. and it would be such an unfortunate thing if i said i wish i could read it for the first time again.

there is no competition when i say this is my favorite book.

the first time i read it, it was fall (2021) of my sophomore year of college - the first ‘real’ year since my freshman year was online. i didn’t know much then.

the second time was summer of 2022 in turkey. i reread in preparation of reading either/or. i still didn’t know much.

i’m about to start my last semester of college, and i know something now. and having a little bit more knowledge from my experience of college, unrequited love, language, and figuring out what i’m doing with my life … made this book EVEN BETTER the third time around

Title: The Applicant
Author: Nazli Koca
My Review: one of my favorite books. couldn’t put it down even tho i have 3 exams to study for. all i have to say is that somehow i read books that correlate perfectly to the moments of my life, never too early and never too late.

Title: The Lying Life of Adults
Author: Elena Ferrante
My Review:
one of the best coming of age stories ever.
one thing i got from this book is that that it has re-affirmed what i believe: people just want to be and feel loved.

Title: Sense and Sensibility
Author: Jane Austen
Additional Authors: Mobile Classics, Ros Ballaster, Джейн Остин, Силвия Желева
My Review: wow. beyond lucky that this was my first jane austen novel. the portrayal of sisterhood, and their respective experiences of unrequited love, was iconic. loved that while they seemed to be complete opposites of each other in the beginning, they both hold parts of their sister, and that showed more as i continued to read. so much drama and emotion, i was in a constant state of awe. couldn’t shut up about it and will never shut up about it.

Title: Translating Myself and Others
Author: Jhumpa Lahiri
My Review:
i really believe this is an amazing book. but i think it is even better for those who grew up in a place in which the language closest to their heart was not the primary language of their environment. to understand and explain how we use language to express ourselves and how to feel connected is so beautiful.

to know more than one language and to understand the feeling of being able to express parts of yourself or your feelings in certain languages is something we should be talking about more. this books was so cool to dive deeply into how language is more than just the words we speak and write.

Title: When Breath Becomes Air
Author: Paul Kalanithi
My Review:
finished this during my 50 min commute from my internship in the bronx to class in manhattan and cried on the subway bc of it.

i think if youre in a place where you dont know if all the work youre doing and the hours youre putting in are worth it... you shoud read this book.

it’s not about encouraging people to not work as much or to relax. but more so to make sure you are doing what you love everyday
